summary.seg: This manuscript, probably copied in the second half of the 11th century, is a Panegyrikon, a collection of texts for reading on particular feast days of the liturgical calendar, mainly homilies, along with some hagiographic works. The selection of feasts covered here runs through the full Byzantine calendar year, from September to August. All the identified authors whose works appear here belong to the patristic era, extending to the early 8th century.

The whole of the original body of the manuscript was copied by a single scribe. The headpieces and initial letters appearing at the beginning of each text are notably varied, some being drawn in red ink alone while others feature painted infill, often in translucent wash. Those in similar materials tend to be grouped together, but no particular logic is apparent in their distribution through the manuscript. Many feature zoomorphic forms, usually snakes, along with the rendering of the letter omicron as a fish. Zoomorphic forms are quite unusual in Greek manuscripts produced in the Byzantine mainstream; still more unusually, human figures occasionally appear as part of the initials (ff. 41v, 364r) The use of these forms and of translucent wash, especially yellow, in rendering them suggests that the manuscript may have been produced in the Greek-speaking communities of southern Italy, where manuscript production was influenced by Latin practice and such features were more common.

At some point, probably in the 15th century, additional quires made of paper were inserted into the manuscript, considerably smaller than the original parchment folios (ff. [219a]-239). These may have been intended as replacements for original folios which had been lost, but this is not certain, since the feasts selected for inclusion form a very selective set and there is no overlap betwen the individual texts featured here and those surviving in the adjacent parts of the original body of the manuscript. Even if these were replacements for losses, it is unclear whether or not the texts found here were the same as those the manuscript originally contained. The manuscript has subsequently lost further folios, while many others have had parts cut or torn away.

At some point during the later 13th-15th centuries, the manuscript was owned by a Byzantine aristocrat named Nikolaos Synadenos, a member of a powerful family of the period and holder of the imperial court title of sebastos, as indicated by a note on ff. 304v-305r. This also identifies him as the anepsios (nephew or cousin) of a cleric named Basil and mentions another relative named Azanos or Azeinos, holder of the court office of megas logariastes. These individuals have not been definitely identified with any known from other sources. The purpose of the note is to record the donation of this manuscript to a monastery which Nikolaos had founded called the Nea Mone (New Monastery, a name borne by various convents of the Byzantine period). In calling down the usual curses on those who would deprive the monastery of its property, the note refers also to a list of other books donated to the institution.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [i] + 1-164, 164[a], 165-219, [219a], 220-235, [235a-d], 236, [236a-b], 237-475 + [ii], in black ink, in Arabic numerals, recto, upper centre.
supportDesc.collation: Part I consists of 63 quires; the quire structure of Part II could not be determined, and for the purposes of this formula it has been notionally treated as a single quire, numbered 31: 14, 28, 310, 4-58, 68-2, 78-2, 88-1, 910-3, 10-118, 128-1, 13-218, 228-1, 23-258, 268-1, 276, 288, 298-2, 306, 3129-2, 328-2, 338-2, 344, 35-408, 41-426, 436-1, 446, 45-558, 566, 5710-1, 588, 596, 602, 618-1, 62-638, 648-1

binding.p: 18th-century full leather binding over couched-laminate boards, with plain pastedowns. There is decorative gold tooling on the spine, and the title Auctores varii in Scripturas MSS tooled in gold on a red label.

physDesc.accMat: A sheet bearing a list of contents is pasted inside the left board.

provenance.p:
Owned in the 13th-15th century by the sebastos
Nikolaos Synadenos Synadenos, Nikolaos and donated by him to a monastery known as the Nea Mone.
Owned by Richard Bentley (1662-1742) Bentley, Richard, 1662-1742 , Master of Trinity, possibly among the manuscripts acquired by him from the Monastery of the Pantokrator on Mount Athos.

history.acquisition: Bequeathed to the college by Bentley.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

support.material: ff. 1-219, 240-475 Parchment (FHHF), of medium thickness and quality.

collation.p: The original body of the manuscript consists of 63 quires, of which one is a single bifolio, two are binia, eight are ternia, three are quinia and the rest are quaternia.

list.item: Quire 68-2 ff. 39-44 The fourth folio has been cancelled, without loss of text; the eighth folio has been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 78-2 ff. 45-50 The first and eighth folios have been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 88-1 ff. 51-57 The first folio has been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 910-3 ff. 58-64 The third and ninth folios have been cancelled, without loss of text; the first folio has been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 128-1 ff. 81-87 The seventh folio has been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 228-1 ff. 160-164, 164[a], 165 The eighth folio has been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 268-4 ff. 190-193 The fifth-eighth folios have been lost or cancelled, with loss of text.
Quire 298-2 ff. 208-213 The first and eighth folios have been lost, with loss of text.

Quire 328-2 ff. 240-245
The first and eighth folios have been lost, with loss of text.

Quire 338-2 ff. 246-251
The first and fourth folios have been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 436-1 ff. 316-320 The sixth folio has been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 5710-1 ff. 421-429 The ninth folio has been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 618-1 ff. 446-452 The second folio has been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 648-1 ff. 469-475 The eighth folio has been cancelled, without loss of text.

collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Arabic numerals, in pencil, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right. They survive on Quires 1-10. The number 6 is misplaced on f. 38r.

There are quire signatures in Greek numerals, in pencil, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right. They appear on Quires 26-30, 32-60, 63-64. The number 31 appears on Quire 30; the substitute folios are apparently treated as a single quire, so the number 33 appears on Quire 32; the number 34 is misplaced on f. 248r; after two unnumbered quires, the number 35 appears on Quire 35 and numbers thereafter accord with the current sequence; the number 57 is placed on f. 422r; the number 61 does not appear and there are no signatures on Quires 61-62; the numbers 62-63 appear on Quires 63-64 (ÎºÏÍ´-Î»Í´, Î»Î²Í´-Î¾Í´, Î¾Î²Í´-Î¾Î³Í´).

supportDesc.condition: There are small losses and tears to the edges of many folios, notably ff. 1-13, 20-30, 165-198, and 467-475. There are larger losses to 132 and longer tears across ff 23, 36, 61, 70, 77, 91, 161, 171-172, 176, 189-190 and 278, with tears along ruling lines to ff. 103-104 and 387. The tear to f. 36 was formerly repaired with stitching, but this has been removed. Stitched repairs to tears to ff. 39, 163, 209, 397 and 471 remain. All or part of the outer margins of ff. 37, 76, 105-111, 117, 127, 144, 158v, 256, 264, 275, 277, 283-284, 288, 291-294, 299-300, 302, 321, 327, 330, 338, 355, 357, 391 and 411 and the lower margins of ff. 165, 185, 205-206, 313, 320, 341-342, 388, 445 and 472 have been cut away. There is pest damage to ff. 1-9 and 467-468. Text has occasionally become, e.g. ff. 29-30. There are occasional small holes (e.g. 122), cockling, creasing, water staining and areas of dirt.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 1-219, 240-475 Two columns of 31 lines. 205 150
Pricking does not survive. Ruled in hardpoint, system Leroy 1, type Leroy 34C2. Text hangs from the lines.

handNote.p: ff. 1-219, 240-475 were copied by Hand A in upright mixed minuscule script, in brown ink, with little variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings usually appear only at the end of lines or in the top line, but occasionally in mid-line. Breathings are both angular and round and mute iota is absent. Use of the double dot is functional only. Nomina sacra are accentuated only when more than three letters long or with enclitics. Nomina sacra strokes are often decorated with an x-shaped mark. The double grave accent and marginal quotation marks are in use. Circumflexes appear enlarged above breathings.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.
Headings are written in Alexandrine majuscule script in red ink. Occasionally the beginning of a heading is written in epigraphic display majuscule (e.g. f. 266v).

decoDesc.decoNote: Most texts are preceded by rectangular headpieces in red ink (e.g. ff. 4v, 9r), in red and brown ink (f. 195v), outlined in brown ink with red and green infill (e.g. ff. 70v, 78r), outlined in red ink with green and blue infill (e.g. f. 321r) or outlined in red ink with green, blue and yellow infill (e.g. f. 351r), or by pylai in red ink (e.g. ff. 166r, f. 176r, 458r), or outlined in red ink with green and blue infill (e.g. f. 304r). The text beginning on f. 129v is preceded by a box headpiece surrounding the heading, in red ink, that on f. 364r by a similar headpiece outlined in red ink with blue and green infill. Painted infill is often in translucent wash.

Texts begin with ornamented initials in materials according with those used for the headpiece each accompanies. These sometimes incorporate blessing hands (e.g. f. 341v) or serpent forms (e.g. ff. 86v, 351r, 458r), or take the form of a fish (e.g. ff. 195v, 298v). The initial on f. 364r incorporates a human form, as does that on f. 41v, where the human figure is in red and brown ink with green infill while the headpiece and the rest of the initial are in red ink only.
Sections begin with simple minor initials in red ink.
On f. 320v are two drawings in brown ink, probably of later origin than the production of the manuscript, one of a saint on horseback and the other of an armoured man holding a sword.
The end of the text on f. 193v is followed by a simple vignette in brown ink.

additions.p: Numbers in Greek numerals, in red ink have been added beside the beginning of each text, numbering them in the sequence in which they appear in the manuscript.

There are occasional brief Greek marginal notes, pen-trials, monocondylia and crude drawings, in various hands (e.g. ff. 105v, 107r, 158r, 245v, 248r, 320v). A pattern has also been made with pin-pricks on f. 71r, alongside some rough drawings of plaited ornament.

A note on ff. 304v-305r records the manuscript's donation to the Nea Mone by the sebastos, imperial oikeios Nikolaos Synadenos, son (?) of the megas logariastes Azanos or Azeinos, cousin or nephew of the reverend father Basil and founder of the Nea Mone, together with a list of other books donated.
The two drawings of armed men on f. 320v are probably the work of a later hand on what was originally a blank page.

history.origin: The main body of the manuscript was probably copied in the second half of the 11th century, as indicated by the style of script. It may have been produced in southern Italy, as suggested by the use of translucent wash, yellow paint and zoomorphic and anthropomorphic forms in the ornament.

msItem.title: Sermo de festo sancti Theodori
msItem.note: Defective at the end, with lacunas: ends PG 39, col. 1837
msItem.explicit: f. 239v ÏÎ¿á¿Ï Î´á½² ÏÎºÎ»Î·ÏÎ¿á¿Ï, Î¿á½Î´á½² ÏÏ Î»Î»Î±Î²á¿Ï á¼¶ÏÎ¿Î½

collation.p: The quire structure of this part could not be determined. It contains 20 complete or largely complete folios, parts of 7 largely lost folios, and stubs of two lost or cancelled folios between ff. 223 and 224.

supportDesc.condition: Almost all of ff. [219a], [235a]-[235d] and [236a]-[236b] has been lost, besides the almost total loss of two folios between ff. 223 and 224, with loss of text. The outer margins of ff. 225 and 231 and the lower margin of f. 227 have been removed, and the upper outer part of ff. 236 and 237-239 have been torn away, with some loss of text. There are small tears to the edges of other folios and areas of dirt.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. [219a] recto-239v A single column of 26 lines. 165 105

handNote.p: ff. [219a]r-239v were copied in mixed minuscule script with variable slant, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear only at the end of lines. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript or absent. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to breathings. The double grave accent is in use.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower comma and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: Texts begin with simple minor initials in red ink.
Transitions between texts are marked by simple vignettes in red ink.

additions.p: There are marginal Greek annotations, pen-trials and monocondylia by various later hands (e.g. ff. 220r, 221r-224r, 226r).

history.origin: The substitute folios were probably copied in the 15th century.
